Hi Erik,

On Apr 11, 2012, at 4:20 AM, Erik Mogensen wrote:

> Hi!  I'm won=
dering about RFC 5988, which says very little about how to process links ot=
her than the word "dereference" (4 times) which might imply using a safe me=
thod to GET something.
> 
> 
> Are Link: headers and <atom:link> elements p=
rimarily designed to support navigation using safe methods?

Good question.=


> 
> Are there any link relations out there that have processing instruct=
ions that say "POST to me to do this" or something similarly unsafe?  I'm o=
nly aware of atom's "edit" link relation, which says something about GET an=
d PUT, but that's the exception, and in any case you typically start by GET=
'ing it anyway, so you're still dereferencing the link.

The meaning of 'ed=
it' is more like: "Here is the primary resource for an entry. If you intend=
 to change the state of the entry, use this URI".

The question of *how* yo=
u do that is up to your intentions - Atompub merely gives a hint to how tha=
t might be done.

> 
> Atom uses the <app:collection> element to indicate t=
hat you can POST entries to a collection;

Again, <app:collection> is telli=
ng you something about the nature of the resource. The POST thing is merely=
 a hint (even atompub cannot constrain servers in any way beyond HTTP). Thi=
nk of the POST thing as a hint to implementors how it SHOULD be done on bot=
h sides.

> HTML uses the <form> element...  Again, shunning links when it =
comes to "unsafety".
> 
> Are links inherently meant to be safe links?

No,=
 I do not think so.

> 
> RFC 4287 says: "The value of "rel" describes the =
meaning of the link, but does not impose any behavioral requirements on Ato=
m Processors."
> 
> Does this mean that the documentation of any given rel =
can NOT say anything about how a link should be used?

Yes, indeed; link re=
l specs cannot constrain servers to behave in a special way. It can provide=
 hints though.  But in the end, the server is always free to do what it wan=
ts and the client needs to expect that.

Usually, these 'how'-things do not=
 change frequently. See my last mail on configuration time.

> 
> On the ot=
her hand, RFC 5988 (which updates 4287) says: "Relation types [...] can spe=
cify the behaviours and properties of the target resource (e.g., allowable =
HTTP methods, request and response media types that must be supported)."

T=
hat is an over-specification ... which, unfortunately, AtomPub contains in =
many places (e.g. GET on <app collections> returning application/atom+xml. =
AtomPUb cannot constrain servers in such a way).

Jan
